content.description: Texas Crude is a fantastic steep crack that is easily protected and soaks up many slightly tight hand jams.
content.protection: Bring a small E-Rock rack heavy on the #1 Camalots.  There are no anchors up top, but you can scramble up and far right to find the descent trail, which leads you to the far right base of the East Face.
content.location: Texas Crude is one of the far left climbs on the East Face.  Find Fear of Flying (splitter, tall, and wide crack in dihedral), and look left for steep hand crack that begins on a small boulder step.

content.description: Fun corner with some stemming moves, deep jamming and face holds sprinkled in.  Top finishes on a beautiful left-leaning hand-fist crack.  Good exposure at the start - consider building an anchor for your belayer.
content.protection: BD #2-#5.  A rock horn and a #3/#4 crack for building a top-rope anchor.  No bolted anchor. Rotten rock 8 feet off the ground.
content.location: Obvious corner 20 feet left of Little Feat.  Walk-off past Conspiracy A Go-Go anchors.

content.description: A strenuous thin line of crimp laybacking above a guillotine blade.
content.protection: tiny nuts for the beginning, the crack opens up a bit as the climbing eases.
content.location: Locate the imposing corner (Fear of Flying) on the East face, just around the corner to the left, past an overhanging dihedral (Aquatic Anxiety) is the obvious chopper flake (4 ft high and sharp).  Shrike climbs the seam starting standing on the tip of this blade.

content.description: A pebble pinching slabby bolted face.  Balancy movement.
content.protection: 3? bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.  There is bad fall potential at the second bolt.
content.location: a few feet to the right of the hand crack (Little Feat) on the upper East side of buzzards roost

content.description: A great crack, thin hands that widen as you ascend.
content.protection: a few medium size cams should be all you need.  There are two bolts off to the right up top which can be used for the anchor.
content.location: Upper east face of Buzzards roost.  If approaching from below, go a few hundred feet up and around to the Right (facing uphill) of the imposing dihedral (Fear of flying).     If approaching from the top, follow the trail down and around to the right (facing downhill) a few hundred feet.

content.description: This is one of the most infamous central Texas climbs, and rightly so.  Fear of Flying is a continuous crack in a beautiful dihedral that widens up top.  Most choose to lieback this beast, which makes the climbing easier, but adds an interesting challenge when placing big gear.
content.protection: Crack widens significantly so bring one or two #6s for the top in addition to the range of medium to large cams needed below.  There are no anchors.  Bring a collection of long slings or an anchor rope to build an adequate anchor above.
content.location: Once you locate the East Face of Buzzard's Roost, find the 80' most prominent dihedral rising above a large triangular block leaning against the wall.

content.description: An overhanging dihedral with somewhat desperate finger locks but great stems, leading to deep jamming as the angle eases.
content.location: On Buzzards East face, left of the imposing dihedral (Fear of Flying) is this minor dihedral with tree's up top.

content.description: This is the East Face of Buzzard's Roost where the classic climbs Texas Crude and Fear of Flying can be found.  Area offers shade and is often quiet due to length of approach, but worth the mellow hike.
